Yvonne Jones}} {{Infobox CanadianMP | honorific-prefix = | name = Yvonne Jones | honorific-suffix = [[Member of Parliament (Canada)|MP]] | image = File:Yvonne Jones.jpg | imagesize = 180px | | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1968|3|15}} | birth_place = [[Mary's Harbour]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]], Canada | residence = | parliament1 = Canadian | office = [[Parliamentary Secretary]] to the [[Minister of Indigenous and Northern Affairs]] | minister = [[Carolyn Bennett]] | term_start = December 2, 2015 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Mark Strahl]] | successor = | riding1 = [[Labrador (electoral district)|Labrador]] |term_start1 = May 13, 2013 |predecessor1 = [[Peter Penashue]] |successor1 = | office2 = [[Leader of the Opposition (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Leader of the Opposition in Newfoundland and Labrador]] | term_start2 = November 13, 2007 | term_end2 = January 3, 2012 | predecessor2 = [[Gerry Reid]] | successor2 = [[Dwight Ball]] | office3 = Leader of the [[Newfoundland and Labrador Liberal Party]] | term_start3 = Interim: November 13, 2007 – May 28, 2011
May 28, 2011 | term_end3 = August 14, 2011 | predecessor3 = [[Gerry Reid]] | successor3 = [[Kevin Aylward]] | assembly4 = Newfoundland and Labrador House of | constituency_AM4 = [[Cartwright-L'Anse au Clair]] | term_start4 = February 22, 1996 | term_end4 = April 8, 2013 | predecessor4 = ''Riding Established'' | successor4 = [[Lisa Dempster]] | office5 = [[Mayor]] of [[Mary's Harbour]] | term_start5 = 1991 | term_end5 = 1996 | party = [[Liberal Party of Canada]] (2013-present) | otherparty = [[Liberal Party of Newfoundland and Labrador]] (1999-2013)
[[Independent (politician)|Independent]] (1996-1999) | website = [http://yvonnejones.liberal.ca/ Official website] | religion = | alma_mater = [[College of the North Atlantic|West Viking College]] | occupation = [[Journalist]], [[Researcher]], [[Politician]] | cabinet = Minister Responsible for the Status of Women (2003) Minister of Fisheries & Aquaculture (2003) }} '''Yvonne Jean Jones''' {{post-nominals|country=CAN|MP}} (born March 15, 1968) is a [[Canada|Canadian]] politician of [[Inuit]] descent[http://www.lop.parl.gc.ca/ParlInfo/compilations/parliament/Aboriginal.aspx?Menu=HOC-Bio&Role=MP&SortColumn=Ethnicity&SortDirection=ASC Inuit, Métis or First Nation Origin] in [[Newfoundland and Labrador]], who was elected to the [[House of Commons of Canada]] in a by-election on May 13, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/liberals-take-labrador-as-jones-wins-big-over-penashue-1.1366435|title=Liberals take Labrador, as Jones wins big over Penashue|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=13 May 2013|accessdate=2 May 2018}} She represents the district of [[Labrador (electoral district)|Labrador]] as a member of the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party]] caucus. On December 2, 2015, she was appointed [[Parliamentary Secretary#Canada|Parliamentary Secretary]] to the [[Minister of Indigenous and Northern Affairs]]. From 1996 to 2013, Jones represented the [[electoral district (Canada)|district]] of [[Cartwright-L'Anse au Clair]] in the [[Newfoundland and Labrador House of Assembly]]. During her career in provincial politics, she served as Minister of Fisheries in Premier [[Roger Grimes]]' government, and later as a leader of the [[Liberal Party of Newfoundland and Labrador]] and [[Leader of the Opposition (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Leader of the Official Opposition]].{{cite news|title=Jones takes on interim Liberal leadership|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/jones-takes-on-interim-liberal-leadership-1.635573|accessdate=8 April 2014|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=15 November 2007}} ==Provincial politics== Jones served as mayor of [[Mary's Harbour]], [[Labrador]] from 1991 to 1996. In 1996, she sought the [[Liberal Party of Newfoundland and Labrador|Liberal Party]] nomination for the provincial electoral district of [[Cartwright-L'Anse au Clair]] in that year's general election. Jones lost the nomination to incumbent [[Danny Dumaresque]], but subsequently ran as an Independent candidate. She was elected to the [[Newfoundland House of Assembly|House of Assembly]] in the [[Newfoundland and Labrador general election, 1996|1996 general election]], defeating Dumaresque, a two-term MHA. Jones became the Liberal Party's candidate for the [[Newfoundland general election, 1999|1999 election]]. She was re-elected in 1999, [[Newfoundland and Labrador general election, 2003|2003]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador general election, 2007|2007]] and [[Newfoundland and Labrador general election, 2011|2011]].{{cite news|title=Yvonne Jones says goodbye to fellow MHAs|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/yvonne-jones-says-goodbye-to-fellow-mhas-1.1328434|accessdate=2 May 2018|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=28 March 2013}} After serving two years as a Parliamentary Secretary Jones was appointed to cabinet In February 2003, by Premier [[Roger Grimes]]. She was sworn in as the Minister of Fisheries and Aquaculture and as the Minister Responsible for the Status of Women.{{cite web|title=Premier Grimes announces new Cabinet|url=http://www.releases.gov.nl.ca/releases/2003/exec/0217n03.htm|publisher=Government of Newfoundland and Labraodr|accessdate=8 June 2013}} Jones held the post till the Liberal government was defeated in the provincial election in October of that year.{{cite news|title=Tories sweep to power in Newfoundland and Labrador|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/tories-sweep-to-power-in-newfoundland-and-labrador-1.392308|accessdate=2 May 2018|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=22 October 2003}} ===Liberal leader=== Jones was one of only three Liberal [[Newfoundland and Labrador House of Assembly|Members of the House of Assembly]] (MHA) re-elected in the [[Newfoundland and Labrador general election, 2007|2007 provincial election]]. On November 15, 2007, she was named the [[Interim leader (Canada)|interim leader]] of the Liberal Party and Official Opposition Leader, after party leader [[Gerry Reid]] was defeated in his own district. Jones became the first woman to lead the Liberal Party in the province. The party originally planned to hold a leadership convention to select a new, permanent leader in 2008, but postponed the vote twice. Jones continued to serve as interim leader during this period of time, and in December 2009, announced her intention to run for the permanent leadership when the convention was to be scheduled.{{cite news|last=Bartlett|first=Dave|title=Jones will run|url=http://www.thetelegram.com/Living/2009-12-17/article-1443587/Jones-will-run/1|accessdate=9 June 2013|newspaper=The Telegram|date=17 December 2009}} On July 30, 2010, Jones was acclaimed Liberal leader after she was the only person to file nomination papers for the position.{{cite news|title=Jones acclaimed Liberal Leader|url=http://www.thetelegram.com/News/Local/2010-07-30/article-1638415/-Jones-acclaimed-Liberal-Leader/1|newspaper=The Telegram|date=30 July 2010}}{{cite news|title=Jones acclaimed N.L. Liberal leader|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/jones-acclaimed-n-l-liberal-leader-1.909387|accessdate=8 April 2014|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=30 July 2010}} She was expected to be sworn in as leader at the party's convention in November of that year, however the convention was delayed when Jones announced in August that she would be taking a leave of absence from her position to undergo treatment for [[breast cancer]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/n-l-liberal-leader-jones-has-breast-cancer-1.909386|title=N.L. Liberal Leader Jones has breast cancer|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=13 August 2010|accessdate=8 April 2014}} She returned to work in early 2011, and was sworn in as Liberal leader at the party's [[Liberal Party of Newfoundland and Labrador leadership election, May 2011|Spring leadership convention]].{{cite news|title=Jones anxious to get back to work|url=http://www.thetelegram.com/News/Local/2011-02-12/article-2221092/Jones-anxious-to-get-back-to-work/1|newspaper=The Telegram|date=12 February 2011}} ====By-elections==== On October 27, 2009, the [[electoral district|district]] of [[The Straits – White Bay North]] held a [[by-election]], to replace [[Executive Council of Newfoundland and Labrador|Minister of Transportation and Works]], [[Trevor Taylor (politician)|Trevor Taylor]], who resigned on October 2, 2009. Liberal candidate [[Marshall Dean]] won the election taking nearly 48% of the vote and defeating the Progressive Conservative candidate by 126 votes.{{cite news|title=Liberals win provincial byelection in rural N.L|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/liberals-win-provincial-byelection-in-rural-n-l-1.832006|accessdate=8 April 2014|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=27 October 2009}} ====Public opinion==== Under Jones' leadership the Liberal Party remained in second place in public opinion polls. After receiving 22% in the [[Newfoundland and Labrador general election, 2007|2007 general election]], the party's support has not risen above those levels. For the majority of time since the election their support has been in the mid-teens according to polls conducted by Corporate Research Associates (CRA).{{cite web|url=http://www.cra.ca/en/home/Newsroom/SupportforConservativesinNLisUnchangedandRemainsHi.aspx/ |title=CRA Poll |publisher=Cra.ca |date=2009-05-30 |accessdate=2010-06-05}} Jones' own popularity had consistently remained lower than her own party's; CRA's quarterly polls on Newfoundland and Labrador politics have found that no more than 11% of those surveyed have felt Jones would make the best premier.[http://www.cra.ca/site-cra/media/CRA/10-2%20NL%20WEB%20TABLES(1).pdf CRA - May 2010 Poll] A [[CJON-DT|NTV]] Telelink poll conducted in February 2011, found that 13% of decided voters would support the Liberal Party and that 12% thought Jones was the best choice to be premier.{{cite web|url=http://ntv.ca/video/?p=11323|title=Provincial Tories Still Have Big Lead: Poll|publisher=NTV News|date=2011-02-16|accessdate=2011-02-17}} The results of the NTV Telelink poll led former Liberal provincial and federal cabinet minister [[John Efford]] to criticize Jones's leadership. Efford said that Jones would not become premier and while he did not call on her to resign as leader, he did say that "it's clear what she ought to do in the face of poor polling results".{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/jones-won-t-become-premier-efford-1.992711|title=Jones won't become premier: Efford|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=17 February 2011|accessdate=8 April 2014}} A CRA poll in March 2011, saw Jones' personal popularity rise to 18%, her highest level since becoming Liberal leader in 2007. Her personal popularity was also tied with that of her party.{{cite web|url=http://cra.ca/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/11-1-NL-Press-Release.pdf|title=Support for the Progressive Conservative Party Remains High|publisher=Corporate Research Associates|date=2011-03-07|accessdate=2011-03-08}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/pcs-dunderdale-still-dominate-poll-1.1061854|title=PCs, Dunderdale Still Dominate: Poll|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=2011-03-07|accessdate=2018-05-02}} On June 7, 2011, CRA released a poll showing that Jones' popularity had dropped slightly to 16% but her party's support had risen to 22%. While the Progressive Conservatives still held a large lead in the poll, at 57%, the Liberals were statistically tied with the [[Newfoundland and Labrador New Democratic Party|New Democrats]], who had the support of 20% of those surveyed.{{cite news|title=Tories drop, NDP surge in new poll|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/tories-drop-ndp-surge-in-new-poll-1.1061853|accessdate=2018-05-02|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=2011-06-07}} ===Resignation=== On August 9, 2011, two months before the provincial election, Jones announced that she was resigning as leader due to a slower recovery from breast cancer than she expected.{{cite news|title=N.L. Liberal leader resigns over health|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/n-l-liberal-leader-resigns-over-health-1.977686|accessdate=2 May 2018|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=8 August 2011}} She sought re-election in her district during the [[Newfoundland and Labrador general election, 2011|2011 provincial election]], and won 71 per cent of the popular vote.{{cite news|title=Yvonne Jones re-elected in Labrador|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/yvonne-jones-re-elected-in-labrador-1.983786|accessdate=2 May 2018|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=11 October 2011}} ==Federal politics== In April 2013, Jones resigned her seat in the Newfoundland and Labrador House of Assembly to run as the Liberal candidate in the federal by-election in [[Labrador (electoral district)|Labrador]] created by the resignation of [[Peter Penashue]].{{cite news|title=Jones declared Liberal candidate for Labrador byelection|url=http://www.thetelegram.com/News/Local/2013-03-27/article-3208578/Jones-declared-Liberal-candidate-for-Labrador-byelection/1|accessdate=12 April 2013|newspaper=The Telegram|date=27 March 2013}}{{cite news|title=Liberals name Jones as candidate in Labrador byelection|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/liberals-name-jones-as-candidate-in-labrador-byelection-1.1314334|accessdate=2 May 2018|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=27 March 2013}} She defeated Penashue to win the seat on May 13, 2013. She was sworn in on June 4, 2013. Upon her Election, Jones was appointed the Liberal critic for Northern Development, the Northern Economic Development Agency, the Arctic Council, the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency, and Search and Rescue. In August 2013, Jones was elected Chair of the Liberal Party of Canada Newfoundland and Labrador caucus. In February 2014, she became Vice-Chair of the Public Accounts committee. On December 2, 2015, she was appointed [[Parliamentary Secretary#Canada|Parliamentary Secretary]] to the [[Minister of Indigenous and Northern Affairs]].{{Cite web|title = Bill Blair, Adam Vaughan among new parliamentary secretaries|url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/trudeau-parliamentary-secretaries-named-1.3346942|website = www.cbc.ca|accessdate = 2015-12-03}} ==Electoral record==
